Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Computing in the Arts - A Community-Building Initiative

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses a recognized need of the 21st century technological society - broadening participation in computing education. The project is transforming STEM education by building a nationwide community of educators, who are teaching students to synthesize the creativity and design of art with the mathematical rigor and formality of computer science, technology, and engineering.

The Computing in the Arts (CITA) model curriculum consists of 50 hours of computing courses, arts courses, and synthesis courses. Graduates of CITA are educated to create, design, and code new creativity tools. From contemporary music, art and theater production, to new forms of animation and digital media, to the visual and audio systems of tomorrow's computers, to revolutionary web applications, CITA prepares students for productive and integrated careers in the information and arts economies. The CITA model maximizes reuse of existing courses and faculty expertise, and thus facilitates adaptation. In this collaborative project the CITA model has already been successfully implemented at the lead institution, where there are currently 46 majors (a 22% increase), mainly from an underserved population - students interested in the arts.

This project focuses on dissemination - successes and synthesis with other complementary approaches with partner institutions to build a strong, diversified community of educators interested in adopting and further developing innovative CITA instructional materials. This community is being forged through three faculty workshops, special sessions at the annual conference for Computer Science Education, and a website of pedagogical materials. The evaluation plan involves an independent evaluator, and various quantitative and qualitative outcomes that assess (a) the formation of a thriving CITA community, (b) dissemination efforts, and (c) the impact on transforming STEM education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Science Foundation has supported the Computing in the Arts (CITA) degree program at the College of Charleston as a model curriculum.  What makes this degree program unique is its synthesis of traditional computing courses and traditional arts courses, across all four years of study.  CITA combines creativity, problem solving, and computational thinking to prepare students for innovative careers in information technology and arts industries, and graduate school.

The following projects (conducted with undergraduate CITA students, and both computer science and arts collaborators) reveal the creative opportunities afforded by the CITA curriculum model, and the power of combining computing and the arts in ways that both contribute as equal partners (i.e., none is subservient to the other):
  • SoundMorpheus is an innovative user interface, which places sounds in space, using conductor-like arm movements.  It may also be used to alter selected sound attributes.  The system combines MIDI and traditional instruments with one or more myoelectric sensors. These components may be physically collocated or distributed in various locales connected via the Internet.  See https://vimeo.com/233398245
  • Diving Into Infinity is a motion-based interactive installation based on “Print Gallery”, a mesmerizing, self-similar lithograph by M.C. Escher.  The system utilizes a Kinect sensor, a video projector, and the Kuatro development framework for motion-based interactive systems.  See https://vimeo.com/233401244
  • Time Jitters is an interactive multimedia art installation. It utilizes two Kinects, four projectors, and four speakers to create an immersive experience, which synthesizes artificial intelligence and human-computer interaction techniques with music and visual art.  It is based on the Kuatro development framework for motion-based interactive systems.  See https://vimeo.com/233708606
Seventy-five (75) faculty members from US institutions were invited to participate in three different workshops (see image1, image2, and image3).  During these workshops, participants were exposed to a well-defined curriculum model in Computing in the Arts (CITA).  The workshops included interactive presentations on topics ranging from New Media in Contemporary Art, to Animation and Virtual Worlds, to Computer Music and Interaction, to Electronics and Arduino, to Creative Synergies, where science and art meet and inform each other as equal partners.

This CITA curriculum model consists of 55+ credit hours of required courses in computer science, mathematics, and an art area (music, visual art, or theatre).  The degree program is structured around several synthesis experiences at the freshman, sophomore, junior, and senior levels, each involving computing and one or more arts areas. The sequence of synthesis courses is
designed to integrate computational thinking in the arts throughout the undergraduate experience.  This curriculum model is motivated by the realization that:
  • Artists and musicians increasingly need to understand the conceptual framework and possibilities of computing - as currently most do not have the necessary computational thinking skills. Twenty-first century artists need to understand computational tools and techniques, so that they may incorporate them extensively, decisively, and effectively into the creative process, in order to achieve their artistic vision. 
  • Similarly, computer scientists increasingly need to incorporate creativity, aesthetics and design into their work. Art enriches computational thinking with creative and aesthetic expression, resulting in new techniques, innovative products, improved problem solving, and original inquiry.
This marriage of design and coding facilitates innovation, creativity, and the design of new tools and techniques.  This is bound to have an impact on intellectual, cultural, and economic growth in our 21st century technological society. 

A six-year longitudinal study revealed that CITA has a significant impact in broadening participation in computing science.  In particular, CITA attracts, retains, and graduates 45% female students (in comparison, the national average of women in computing is 20%).  Also, the students attracted are distinct (in terms of their mathematical background) from those pursuing traditional CS degrees.  CITA, in addition to doubling the amount of women in computing, also broadens participation by attracting a new, distinct student profile (i.e., those with strong arts backgrounds and interests).  As these students complete their degree, they enter the workforce, adding a unique, new type of expertise, namely professionals who can combine computing with creativity and design, and produce significant and innovative computational concepts and artifacts.

The project has also produced two new textbooks; 9 international journal and conference publications; three invited talks; three computer music performances; one interactive art installation; and an international fellowship (sponsored by Fulbright and the Niarchos Foundation) to explore cross-institution CITA initiatives, including new educational models, curriculum co-development, research and performance projects, and student/faculty exchanges.

A representative workshop conducted under this project is available here - http://compsci.cofc.edu/nsf-cita-workshop.php .  The CITA degree program is available here - http://cita.cofc.edu .
